text:
What's everyone's biggest content pet peeves?

I think mine is when people use 2 periods after a space. That in itself isn't sooo bad, but I've found that people who do that do not do it consistently, so about half of the sentences in a piece have 1 space and half have 2 and it makes me way too upset

elements.text:

text: I can't believe people still do this in 2020. Hasn't Word stopped this from happening yet?

elements.text: I can't believe people still do this in 2020. Hasn't Word stopped this from happening yet?

text: Apparently not, I see it all the time from clients. Even people in their 30s! I don't know where they learned it because it's a holdover from typewriters, so I understand older people doing it, but young people have no excuse

text: I can't believe anybody under 30 has ever done this or understands why this was ever a thing.

elements.text: I can't believe anybody under 30 has ever done this or understands why this was ever a thing.

text:
I *feel* this in a big way, but the two people I had to break from this habit we’re in their mid-40's.

I did have to break many of the content writers that were fresh out of school out of the 5-sentence paragraph habit. That was painful.

text:
<@U0109NWK58A> I was only ever taught to write for a "reading book" at school/college.
When I started a journalism degree, I learned people don't like reading chunks.
When I started working in content marketing, paragraphs became a thing of the past.

text:
Mine is what I’ll call the “Seth Godin” writing style. I can only describe it as a call-and-response with a bunch of short sentences and an unearned “what im saying is so smart” tone. Something like:

```Some of you have been emailing me about my bread recipe. I used to be like you.

But then one day I woke up.

Bread making is not what you think it is. And if you mess it up, you are going to get CRUSHED.

Most people don't know this.```

elements.text: Mine is what I’ll call the “Seth Godin” writing style. I can only describe it as a call-and-response with a bunch of short sentences and an unearned “what im saying is so smart” tone. Something like:

Some of you have been emailing me about my bread recipe. I used to be like you.

But then one day I woke up.

Bread making is not what you think it is. And if you mess it up, you are going to get CRUSHED.

Most people don't know this.

text: Marketers are rediscovering copywriting right now. "OMG, you can write _just_ for conversions!" Yep! It's great for getting people to fill out forms and like your LinkedIn post, just like it's great at selling Bragg's Apple Cider Vinegar (which I love, btw). Then everyone will start writing like that until we're sick of it and some genius will "discover" thought leadership content. That's marketing though! Every old trend is resold as some new invention :woman-shrugging:

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text:
I did one of those LinkedIn giveaways where I made everyone say "Good idea" for my Idea Doc content marketing template that I use w/ co's just starting out.

But everyone here is super pro and I don't want you to succumb to such silly LinkedIn antics.

text: <@U012GHRAHDK> that made me think of another one, which is people putting punctuation outside of quotes like "this". At first I mostly saw this from programmers (which makes sense, that's how you write code) but I see it all the time now, from people from a variety of backgrounds.

text:
*Writing pet peeve:* More than half of the articles I receive for editing start with some form of:

"Throughout history..."
"[topic] is becoming more and more important throughout the world."

*Grammar pet peeve:* Improper hyphen usage. I've had many writers tell me that hyphens are just a style choice.

*Nitpickier grammar pet peeve:* Misuse of sign-up vs. sign up vs. signup.

elements.text: Writing pet peeve:

More than half of the articles I receive for editing start with some form of:

"Throughout history..."
"[topic] is becoming more and more important throughout the world."
Grammar pet peeve:
Improper hyphen usage. I've had many writers tell me that hyphens are just a style choice.
Nitpickier grammar pet peeve:
Misuse of sign-up vs. sign up vs. signup.

text:
I dislike when publications tie a neat little bow on every post they write.

For example, when difficult practices like copywriting, content, freelancing, or SEO get boiled down to 7 easy steps _in every post_.

I'm all for actionable, and I'm all for tips. And I know humans like stuff to fit in boxes. But you gotta acknowledge the gray, gritty, misshapen stuff too.

Otherwise it starts to feel inauthentic.

text: <@UUH2ESL66> Oh no! What is the difference between each of those "sign ups"? :flushed:

elements.text: Oh no! What is the difference between each of those "sign ups"?

text:
<@U013L0U4YSU> Glad you asked!

Sign up is a verb. "Please sign up for the event."

Signup is a noun "The signup is available here..." or adjective "The signup form is available..."

Sign-up is just an alternative spelling of signup :)

elements.text:
